title: Defence services may have a combined leader after PM Narendra Modi’s involvement
text:
Defence services may have a combined leader after PM Narendra Modi’s involvement Defence services may have a combined leader after PM Narendra Modi’s involvement After the intervention of Prime Minister Narendra Modi, armed forces and defence ministry are coming to an agreement over another 4-star military officer who will be the PermanentChairman of Chiefs of Staff Committee (PC-CoSC). By: FE Online | New Delhi | Updated: February 21, 2017 12:18 PM Prime Minister Narendra Modi focused on the jointness of defence forces. (PTI) 
After the intervention of Prime Minister Narendra Modi , armed forces and defence ministry are coming to an agreement over another 4-star military officer who will be the PermanentChairman of Chiefs of Staff Committee (PC-CoSC). The idea of making a single-point military advisor to the government emerged after Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s announcement during the Combined Commanders Conference at Dehradun last month. The news was confirmed to The Indian Express by two military officers who attended the conference and said Prime Minister’s focus was on combining the three defence forces. 
The officials, however, cleared that there was no mention of integrating the three services and neither did the Prime Minister mentioned any plans about it. “The decision to have a Chief of Defence Staff (CDS) or PC-CoSC is finally a political one. But the three services have all agreed to the idea of a PC-CoSC, who will look after common functions of the three services like intelligence, procurement and perhaps training,” a senior military official said.

The idea of creating the single-point military commander post was suggested by the Group of Ministers (GoM) report on national security in 2001. The members then suggested that the new commander will be senior to the three military chiefs. However, the proposal wasn’t accepted by the political parties and defence services. 
In 2012, the Naresh Chandra committee recommended a PC-CoSC, an appointment at par with the three service chiefs. This is an idea which seems to be gaining ground among the defence services and the ministry and Defence Minister Manohar Parrikar has repeatedly said that he will make his recommendation to the Cabinet after the ministry considers the report of the expert committee chaired by Lt General D B Shekatkar (retired).

A top official from the defence ministry revealed that the proposal has been studied and an action will be taken over it soon. The top defence ministry official also confirmed that they had identified certain senior posts in the ministry to be occupied by military officers.
